value.text: Introduction to groups... Living beings

Formation of Planets

Planets originate from clouds of dust (History Tracers, ; NASA, Stars). As the formation process commences, these particles are initially minuscule in size (Morfill, G., et al., , pp. 212, 216 - 217 ; Birnstiel, T., et al., , pp. 42). As the cloud begins to collapse under gravitational forces, the dust grains gradually coalesce and collide, eventually forming larger structures known as planetesimals (Birnstiel, T., et al., , pp. 46 - 47).

Practice 1: Creating planetesimals
Place a few grains, such as sand or beans, on top of a piece of paper. Ensure they are spaced apart.
Although not visible, the paper and the space around, representing the cosmic space, contains more gas than grains.
Slowly begin to move and fold the paper until the grains come together, forming your own planetesimal.
When they grains are together, you have your "planetesimal".

Before proceeding further, it's essential to note a key observation: conventional teaching suggests that gravity attracts matter based on the mass of the object. However, this principle does not hold true for all known models, as explained by by Sabine Hossenfelder (Hossenfelder, Sabine, ; Hossenfelder, Sabine, ) and Dr. Don Lincoln (Lincoln, Don, , Fermilab), and Quantum Fracture (QuantumFracture, ).

The planetesimal continues to attract particles, gradually forming a larger structure known as a protoplanet. Over time, through a slow accretion process, the protoplanet accumulates more matter until it reaches the status of a fully-fledged planet (Leinhardt, Zoe M., and Derek C. Richardson., ).

While there is a general consensus on the process of planetary formation, recent discussions have led to modifications in the definition of a planet to: an object of sufficient size, rounded by its gravitational orbit around a star, capable of gravitationally clearing its orbital neighborhood of other celestial objects (Library of Congress, ; Hogeback, J., ).

Molecules

Planetesimals form through the collision and aggregation of small grains, eventually evolving into massive structures. However, amidst these processes lies an intermediate stage that remains unexplored: molecules.

Molecules consist of two or more atoms bonded together to form a pure substance, capable of retaining its chemical properties even when divided (Britannica, T. Editors of Encyclopaedia).

The first space-borne molecules likely occurred during the recombination period (NASA, Universe), a phase characterized by the absence of dust grains but the presence of abundant atoms. This environment facilitated the formation of small molecules, including hydrogen molecules (H2) (Lepp, S., and J. M. Shull, 1984). Technological advancements have vastly improved our understanding of interstellar space, leading to the identification of over 170 different molecules that are also part of living beings, including essential compounds such as water (H2O), and ammonia (NH3) (Tielens, A. G. G. M., , pp. 1023 - 1024 ).

Interestingly, some molecules integral to terrestrial lifeforms have also been detected beyond our planet's confines. Alongside water, various acids have been identified (7-b4d7-49b7-a07e-07062f690d2a'); return false;">Liu, Sheng‐Yuan, et al., ; Sanz-Novo, Miguel, et al., ; Puletti, Fabrizio, et al., ). The transportation of these molecules to planets, potentially via comets (McKay, Adam J., and Nathan X. Roth.), could have played a pivotal role in facilitating the emergence of life.

Grouping for life

As inhabitants of this planet, we are comprised of a diverse array of molecules, much like the plants and animals that surround us. This observation, could lead us to the conclusion that with molecules and a planet we have life. If so, one might expect nearby planets to also support life. What are we missing?

Firstly, it is essential to delineate regions within stellar systems where life-supporting planets may exist. These areas, known as habitable zones, impose specific criteria for planetary habitability (Ramirez, Ramses, ; Sacani, Sérgio, ):

  • Presence of liquid water on the planet's surface (De La Torre, Lizbeth B., ).
  • Composition of the planet, which must be rocky akin to Earth.
  • Adequate energy received from a star to maintain temperatures conducive to life as we know it.
  • Existence of natural processes such as tectonic activity that facilitate essential cycles of carbon and silicon (National Geographic).

Furthermore, it is imperative to recognize the correlation between habitable zones and the size of the host star (Waltham, David, ).

When a planet is formed in a habitable zone, the molecules to make the life in this planet can finally to group, but as Carl H. Gibson et al. highlight, the process to create life in the planet can be expanded to bigger horizons (Gibson, Carl H., et al., ):

  • Precursors to life may originate within the centers of protogalaxies (Gibson, Carl H., et al., , pp. 10).
  • Life may have arisen from "seeds" rather than from an "inorganic soup" for reasons of efficiency (Gibson, Carl H., et al., , pp. 21).
  • The emergence of life via abiogenesis is not guaranteed (Gibson, Carl H., et al., , pp. 22 - 23).

It is necessary to remember for the reader, that contradictions are part of the science, and we cannot discard completely the idea of an inorganic soup. Lena Vicente et al. studied different ways to test hypothesis to arise of the life (Vincent, Lena, et al., ).

The timing of life's of emergence has direct relationship with the chosen model (Gibson, Carl H., et al., , pp. 10 - 11). According to the HGD model, life emerged subsequent to the formation of protogalaxies (Gibson, Carl H., et al., , pp. 11), whereas in the ΛCDMHC (Gibson, Carl H., and Rudolph E. Schild., ), it happens more recently (Gibson, Carl H., et al., , pp. 11). In the case of Earth, the advent of life occurred millions of years after the planet's formation (Harari, Yuval Noah, , pp. 14, 18).

text.question: The steps to make a planet are: planets lose mass by gravitational forces making a protoplanet that are disintegrated into planetesimals, finally it is transformed into dust grain?
text.additionalInfo: The question describes the inverse process. Remember that in nature, structures always build from the smallest to the largest.

text.question: When a pure substance is broken, can we still identify the molecules because they keep chemical properties?
text.additionalInfo: Molecules are made up of smaller identical entities. For example, when water molecules are separated, we still expect to have water.

text.question: Do we have the life, living beings, in a planet only with specific conditions?
text.additionalInfo: Not all planets can support life as we know it; this can be observed in our own solar system.
